column2: to get up / to wake up
column3:
Details: おきます (okimasu)
Meaning: “to get up / to wake up”
Use Context: Verb for waking up from sleep or getting out of bed.
Placement in sentence: Verb; often with particle に (time) or at the end of a sentence.
Examples:
1. まいあさしちじにおきます。(Maiasa shichiji ni okimasu.) → I wake up at 7 every morning.
2. はやくおきます。(Hayaku okimasu.) → I get up early.
3. あしたはろくじにおきます。(Ashita wa rokuji ni okimasu.) → Tomorrow I will wake up at 6.
Politeness: Polite (ます-form). Casual: おきる.

column2: to sleep / to go to bed
column3:
Details: ねます (nemasu)
Meaning: “to sleep / to go to bed”
Use Context: Verb for lying down and sleeping.
Placement in sentence: Verb; often with に (time).
Examples:
1. じゅういちじにねます。(Juuichi-ji ni nemasu.) → I go to bed at 11.
2. けさはおそくねました。(Kesa wa osoku nemashita.) → I slept late this morning.
3. あしたはやくねます。(Ashita hayaku nemasu.) → I will sleep early tomorrow.
Politeness: Polite (ます-form). Casual: ねる.

Details: はたらきます (hatarakimasu)
Meaning: “to work”
Use Context: Verb for performing a job, working at a company.
Placement in sentence: Verb; often with で (place of work).
Examples:
1. かいしゃではたらきます。(Kaisha de hatarakimasu.) → I work at a company.
2. にほんではたらきたいです。(Nihon de hatarakitai desu.) → I want to work in Japan.
3. わたしのちちはぎんこうではたらきます。(Watashi no chichi wa ginkou de hatarakimasu.) → My father works at a bank.
Politeness: Polite (ます-form). Casual: はたらく.

column2: to rest / to take a break / to take time off
column3:
Details: やすみます (yasumimasu)
Meaning: “to rest / to take a break / to take time off”
Use Context: Used for resting, holidays, skipping work/school.
Placement in sentence: Verb; often with を (object) or particle から.
Examples:
1. きょうはやすみます。(Kyou wa yasumimasu.) → I will rest today.
2. がっこうをやすみます。(Gakkou o yasumimasu.) → I take a day off school.
3. しごとをやすみたいです。(Shigoto o yasumitai desu.) → I want to take a break from work.
Politeness: Polite (ます-form). Casual: やすむ.

Details: べんきょうします (benkyou shimasu)
Meaning: “to study”
Use Context: Verb for studying/learning.
Placement in sentence: Verb; often with を for subject.
Examples:
1. にほんごをべんきょうします。(Nihongo o benkyou shimasu.) → I study Japanese.
2. まいにちべんきょうします。(Mainichi benkyou shimasu.) → I study every day.
3. としょかんでべんきょうします。(Toshokan de benkyou shimasu.) → I study in the library.
Politeness: Polite (します-form). Casual: べんきょうする.

Details: おわります (owarimasu)
Meaning: “to finish / to end”
Use Context: Verb for something being completed.
Placement in sentence: Verb; often with を or が.
Examples:
1. じゅぎょうはごじにおわります。(Jugyou wa goji ni owarimasu.) → Class ends at 5 o’clock.
2. しごとがおわりました。(Shigoto ga owarimashita.) → The work has finished.
3. テストをおわります。(Tesuto o owarimasu.) → I finish the test.
Politeness: Polite (ます-form). Casual: おわる.

Details: デパート (depaato)
Meaning: “department store”
Use Context: Refers to large retail department stores.
Placement in sentence: Noun; with は, で, に.
Examples:
1. デパートでかいものをします。(Depaato de kaimono o shimasu.) → I shop at the department store.
2. デパートはにぎやかです。(Depaato wa nigiyaka desu.) → The department store is lively.
3. あのデパートはおおきいです。(Ano depaato wa ookii desu.) → That department store is big.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: ぎんこう (ginkou)
Meaning: “bank”
Use Context: Refers to financial institutions.
Placement in sentence: Noun; with は, で, に.
Examples:
1. ぎんこうではたらきます。(Ginkou de hatarakimasu.) → I work at a bank.
2. ぎんこうはあそこです。(Ginkou wa asoko desu.) → The bank is over there.
3. ぎんこうでおかねをおろします。(Ginkou de okane o oroshimasu.) → I withdraw money at the bank.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: ゆうびんきょく (yuubinkyoku)
Meaning: “post office”
Use Context: Refers to Japanese postal service buildings.
Placement in sentence: Noun; with は, に, で.
Examples:
1. ゆうびんきょくでてがみをだします。(Yuubinkyoku de tegami o dashimasu.) → I send a letter at the post office.
2. ゆうびんきょくはどこですか。(Yuubinkyoku wa doko desu ka.) → Where is the post office?
3. ゆうびんきょくにいきます。(Yuubinkyoku ni ikimasu.) → I go to the post office.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: としょかん (toshokan)
Meaning: “library”
Use Context: Place where books are kept for reading/borrowing.
Placement in sentence: Noun; with は, で, に.
Examples:
1. としょかんでほんをよみます。(Toshokan de hon o yomimasu.) → I read books in the library.
2. としょかんはしずかです。(Toshokan wa shizuka desu.) → The library is quiet.
3. としょかんにいきます。(Toshokan ni ikimasu.) → I go to the library.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: びじゅつかん (bijutsukan)
Meaning: “art museum”
Use Context: Refers to museums specializing in fine arts.
Placement in sentence: Noun; with は, で, に.
Examples:
1. びじゅつかんでえをみます。(Bijutsukan de e o mimasu.) → I see pictures at the art museum.
2. びじゅつかんはゆうめいです。(Bijutsukan wa yuumei desu.) → The art museum is famous.
3. びじゅつかんにいきたいです。(Bijutsukan ni ikitai desu.) → I want to go to the art museum.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: いま (ima)
Meaning: “now”
Use Context: Refers to the current time.
Placement in sentence: Adverb/noun; with は, が, に.
Examples:
1. いまはなんじですか。(Ima wa nanji desu ka.) → What time is it now?
2. いまべんきょうします。(Ima benkyou shimasu.) → I am studying now.
3. いまはじゅぎょうです。(Ima wa jugyou desu.) → Now it is class.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: ～じ (~ji)
Meaning: “~ o’clock”
Use Context: Suffix for telling time.
Placement in sentence: Attaches to numbers (いちじ, にじ, さんじ…).
Examples:
1. いまはさんじです。(Ima wa san-ji desu.) → It’s 3 o’clock now.
2. わたしはろくじにおきます。(Watashi wa roku-ji ni okimasu.) → I wake up at 6 o’clock.
3. しちはんにねます。(Shichi-ji han ni nemasu.) → I sleep at 7:30.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: ～ふん (~fun)
Meaning: “~ minutes”
Use Context: Suffix for minutes when telling time.
Placement in sentence: Attaches to numbers (いっぷん, にふん, さんぷん…).
Examples:
1. ごふんまちます。(Go-fun machimasu.) → I wait for 5 minutes.
2. いまはじゅっぷんです。(Ima wa juppun desu.) → It is 10 minutes.
3. さんじじゅうごふんです。(San-ji juu-go-fun desu.) → It’s 3:15.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: はん (han)
Meaning: “half past (30 minutes)”
Use Context: Used with hours to indicate half past.
Placement in sentence: Follows time nouns (～じ).
Examples:
1. しちはんにおきます。(Shichi-han ni okimasu.) → I wake up at 7:30.
2. ごじはんにおわります。(Go-ji han ni owarimasu.) → It ends at 5:30.
3. いまはにじはんです。(Ima wa ni-ji han desu.) → It’s 2:30 now.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: なんじ (nan-ji)
Meaning: “what time?”
Use Context: Interrogative for asking the hour.
Placement in sentence: Question word; usually with particle に.
Examples:
1. いまはなんじですか。(Ima wa nan-ji desu ka.) → What time is it now?
2. あしたなんじにおきますか。(Ashita nan-ji ni okimasu ka.) → What time do you get up tomorrow?
3. テストはなんじにはじまりますか。(Tesuto wa nan-ji ni hajimarimasu ka.) → What time does the test begin?
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: なんぷん (nan-pun)
Meaning: “what minute?”
Use Context: Interrogative for asking exact minutes.
Placement in sentence: Used with に or ですか.
Examples:
1. いまなんぷんですか。(Ima nan-pun desu ka.) → What minute is it now?
2. バスはなんぷんにきますか。(Basu wa nan-pun ni kimasu ka.) → At what minute does the bus come?
3. なんぷんまちますか。(Nan-pun machimasu ka.) → How many minutes do (we) wait?
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: ごぜん (gozen)
Meaning: “AM / morning (before noon)”
Use Context: Used with times before noon.
Placement in sentence: Used before numbers (ごぜんしちじ).
Examples:
1. ごぜんしちじにおきます。(Gozen shichi-ji ni okimasu.) → I wake up at 7 AM.
2. ごぜんくじにいきます。(Gozen ku-ji ni ikimasu.) → I go at 9 AM.
3. かいぎはごぜんじゅうじです。(Kaigi wa gozen juu-ji desu.) → The meeting is at 10 AM.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: ごご (gogo)
Meaning: “PM / afternoon/evening (after noon)”
Use Context: Used with times after noon.
Placement in sentence: Used before numbers (ごごいちじ).
Examples:
1. ごごにじにしごとをします。(Gogo ni-ji ni shigoto o shimasu.) → I work at 2 PM.
2. しけんはごごさんじです。(Shiken wa gogo san-ji desu.) → The exam is at 3 PM.
3. ごごろくじにかえります。(Gogo roku-ji ni kaerimasu.) → I return at 6 PM.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: あさ (asa)
Meaning: “morning”
Use Context: Refers to early hours of the day.
Placement in sentence: Noun/adverb of time; with は, に.
Examples:
1. あさべんきょうします。(Asa benkyou shimasu.) → I study in the morning.
2. あさごはんをたべます。(Asa-gohan o tabemasu.) → I eat breakfast.
3. あさはさむいです。(Asa wa samui desu.) → The morning is cold.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: ひる (hiru)
Meaning: “noon / midday / daytime”
Use Context: Refers to midday and afternoon.
Placement in sentence: Noun; with は, に.
Examples:
1. ひるやすみをします。(Hiru-yasumi o shimasu.) → I take a lunch break.
2. ひるにあいます。(Hiru ni aimasu.) → I meet at noon.
3. ひるごはんをたべます。(Hiru-gohan o tabemasu.) → I eat lunch.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: ばん (ban)
Meaning: “evening / night”
Use Context: Refers to the evening hours.
Placement in sentence: Noun; with は, に.
Examples:
1. こんばんばんごはんをたべます。(Konban bangohan o tabemasu.) → I eat dinner tonight.
2. ばんはしずかです。(Ban wa shizuka desu.) → Evenings are quiet.
3. まいばんほんをよみます。(Maiban hon o yomimasu.) → I read books every evening.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: よる (yoru)
Meaning: “night”
Use Context: Refers to nighttime.
Placement in sentence: Noun; with は, に.
Examples:
1. よるべんきょうします。(Yoru benkyou shimasu.) → I study at night.
2. よるおそくねます。(Yoru osoku nemasu.) → I go to bed late at night.
3. よるはしずかです。(Yoru wa shizuka desu.) → Night is quiet.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: おととい (ototoi)
Meaning: “the day before yesterday”
Use Context: Time expression for two days ago.
Placement in sentence: Adverb; with は, に.
Examples:
1. おとといえいがをみました。(Ototoi eiga o mimashita.) → I watched a movie the day before yesterday.
2. おとといはやすみでした。(Ototoi wa yasumi deshita.) → The day before yesterday was a holiday.
3. おとといともだちにあいました。(Ototoi tomodachi ni aimashita.) → I met a friend the day before yesterday.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: きのう (kinou)
Meaning: “yesterday”
Use Context: Refers to the previous day.
Placement in sentence: Adverb; with は, に.
Examples:
1. きのうほんをよみました。(Kinou hon o yomimashita.) → I read a book yesterday.
2. きのうはにちようびでした。(Kinou wa nichiyoubi deshita.) → Yesterday was Sunday.
3. きのうともだちとあそびました。(Kinou tomodachi to asobimashita.) → I hung out with a friend yesterday.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: きょう (kyou)
Meaning: “today”
Use Context: Refers to the current day.
Placement in sentence: Adverb; with は, に.
Examples:
1. きょうはあついです。(Kyou wa atsui desu.) → Today is hot.
2. きょうべんきょうします。(Kyou benkyou shimasu.) → I study today.
3. きょうしけんがあります。(Kyou shiken ga arimasu.) → There is an exam today.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: あした (ashita)
Meaning: “tomorrow”
Use Context: Refers to the next day.
Placement in sentence: Adverb; with は, に.
Examples:
1. あしたはやすみます。(Ashita wa yasumimasu.) → I will rest tomorrow.
2. あしたにほんへいきます。(Ashita Nihon e ikimasu.) → I will go to Japan tomorrow.
3. あしたのテストはむずかしいです。(Ashita no tesuto wa muzukashii desu.) → Tomorrow’s test is difficult.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: あさって (asatte)
Meaning: “the day after tomorrow”
Use Context: Refers to two days ahead.
Placement in sentence: Adverb; with は, に.
Examples:
1. あさってテストがあります。(Asatte tesuto ga arimasu.) → There is a test the day after tomorrow.
2. あさってはにちようびです。(Asatte wa nichiyoubi desu.) → The day after tomorrow is Sunday.
3. あさってともだちにあいます。(Asatte tomodachi ni aimasu.) → I will meet my friend the day after tomorrow.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: けさ (kesa)
Meaning: “this morning”
Use Context: Refers to the morning of the current day.
Placement in sentence: Adverb; with は, に.
Examples:
1. けさしちじにおきました。(Kesa shichi-ji ni okimashita.) → I woke up at 7 this morning.
2. けさはさむかったです。(Kesa wa samukatta desu.) → It was cold this morning.
3. けさべんきょうしました。(Kesa benkyou shimashita.) → I studied this morning.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: こんばん (konban)
Meaning: “this evening / tonight”
Use Context: Refers to the evening/night of the current day.
Placement in sentence: Adverb; with は, に.
Examples:
1. こんばんえいがをみます。(Konban eiga o mimasu.) → I will watch a movie tonight.
2. こんばんばんごはんをたべます。(Konban bangohan o tabemasu.) → I will eat dinner tonight.
3. こんばんあめがふります。(Konban ame ga furimasu.) → It will rain tonight.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: やすみ (yasumi)
Meaning: “rest / holiday / absence”
Use Context: Refers to a day off, rest, or holiday.
Placement in sentence: Noun; with は, に, の.
Examples:
1. きのうはやすみでした。(Kinou wa yasumi deshita.) → Yesterday was a holiday.
2. あしたやすみがあります。(Ashita yasumi ga arimasu.) → There is a holiday tomorrow.
3. しゅうまつにやすみます。(Shuumatsu ni yasumimasu.) → I rest on weekends.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: ひるやすみ (hiru-yasumi)
Meaning: “lunch break”
Use Context: Refers to a midday break.
Placement in sentence: Noun; with は, に.
Examples:
1. ひるやすみにともだちとあいます。(Hiru-yasumi ni tomodachi to aimasu.) → I meet my friend at lunch break.
2. ひるやすみはじゅうにじです。(Hiru-yasumi wa juu-ni-ji desu.) → Lunch break is at 12.
3. ひるやすみにべんきょうします。(Hiru-yasumi ni benkyou shimasu.) → I study at lunch break.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: まいあさ (maiasa)
Meaning: “every morning”
Use Context: Expression of frequency.
Placement in sentence: Adverb; often at start of sentence.
Examples:
1. まいあさろくじにおきます。(Maiasa roku-ji ni okimasu.) → I get up at 6 every morning.
2. まいあさべんきょうします。(Maiasa benkyou shimasu.) → I study every morning.
3. まいあさコーヒーをのみます。(Maiasa koohii o nomimasu.) → I drink coffee every morning.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: まいばん (maiban)
Meaning: “every evening / every night”
Use Context: Expression of frequency.
Placement in sentence: Adverb.
Examples:
1. まいばんほんをよみます。(Maiban hon o yomimasu.) → I read books every night.
2. まいばんテレビをみます。(Maiban terebi o mimasu.) → I watch TV every night.
3. まいばんおそくねます。(Maiban osoku nemasu.) → I go to bed late every night.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: まいにち (mainichi)
Meaning: “every day”
Use Context: Expression of daily frequency.
Placement in sentence: Adverb.
Examples:
1. まいにちべんきょうします。(Mainichi benkyou shimasu.) → I study every day.
2. まいにちしごとをします。(Mainichi shigoto o shimasu.) → I work every day.
3. まいにちテレビをみます。(Mainichi terebi o mimasu.) → I watch TV every day.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: げつようび (getsuyoubi)
Meaning: “Monday”
Use Context: Refers to days of the week.
Placement in sentence: Noun; with は, に.
Examples:
1. げつようびにがっこうにいきます。(Getsuyoubi ni gakkou ni ikimasu.) → I go to school on Monday.
2. げつようびはやすみです。(Getsuyoubi wa yasumi desu.) → Monday is a holiday.
3. げつようびにテストがあります。(Getsuyoubi ni tesuto ga arimasu.) → There is a test on Monday.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: かようび (kayoubi)
Meaning: “Tuesday”
Use Context: Refers to days of the week.
Placement in sentence: Noun; with は, に.
Examples:
1. かようびにしごとをします。(Kayoubi ni shigoto o shimasu.) → I work on Tuesday.
2. かようびはにほんごのじゅぎょうです。(Kayoubi wa Nihongo no jugyou desu.) → Tuesday is Japanese class.
3. かようびにテストがあります。(Kayoubi ni tesuto ga arimasu.) → There is a test on Tuesday.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: すいようび (suiyoubi)
Meaning: “Wednesday”
Use Context: Refers to days of the week.
Placement in sentence: Noun; with は, に.
Examples:
1. すいようびにともだちにあいます。(Suiyoubi ni tomodachi ni aimasu.) → I meet my friend on Wednesday.
2. すいようびはやすみです。(Suiyoubi wa yasumi desu.) → Wednesday is a holiday.
3. すいようびにテストがあります。(Suiyoubi ni tesuto ga arimasu.) → There is a test on Wednesday.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: もくようび (mokuyoubi)
Meaning: “Thursday”
Use Context: Refers to days of the week.
Placement in sentence: Noun; with は, に.
Examples:
1. もくようびにかいぎがあります。(Mokuyoubi ni kaigi ga arimasu.) → There is a meeting on Thursday.
2. もくようびはやすみです。(Mokuyoubi wa yasumi desu.) → Thursday is a holiday.
3. もくようびにしごとをします。(Mokuyoubi ni shigoto o shimasu.) → I work on Thursday.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: きんようび (kin'youbi)
Meaning: “Friday”
Use Context: Refers to days of the week.
Placement in sentence: Noun; with は, に.
Examples:
1. きんようびにえいがをみます。(Kin'youbi ni eiga o mimasu.) → I watch a movie on Friday.
2. きんようびはしごとです。(Kin'youbi wa shigoto desu.) → Friday is a workday.
3. きんようびにテストがあります。(Kin'youbi ni tesuto ga arimasu.) → There is a test on Friday.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: どようび (doyoubi)
Meaning: “Saturday”
Use Context: Refers to days of the week.
Placement in sentence: Noun; with は, に.
Examples:
1. どようびにパーティーがあります。(Doyoubi ni paatii ga arimasu.) → There is a party on Saturday.
2. どようびはやすみです。(Doyoubi wa yasumi desu.) → Saturday is a holiday.
3. どようびにしごとをしません。(Doyoubi ni shigoto o shimasen.) → I don’t work on Saturday.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: にちようび (nichiyoubi)
Meaning: “Sunday”
Use Context: Refers to days of the week.
Placement in sentence: Noun; with は, に.
Examples:
1. にちようびにかぞくとあそびます。(Nichiyoubi ni kazoku to asobimasu.) → I spend time with family on Sunday.
2. にちようびはやすみです。(Nichiyoubi wa yasumi desu.) → Sunday is a holiday.
3. にちようびにえいがをみます。(Nichiyoubi ni eiga o mimasu.) → I watch a movie on Sunday.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: なんようび (nan-youbi)
Meaning: “what day of the week?”
Use Context: Interrogative word asking which weekday.
Placement in sentence: Question noun; with は, に.
Examples:
1. きょうはなんようびですか。(Kyou wa nan-youbi desu ka.) → What day is it today?
2. テストはなんようびですか。(Tesuto wa nan-youbi desu ka.) → What day is the test?
3. かいぎはなんようびですか。(Kaigi wa nan-youbi desu ka.) → On what day is the meeting?
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: ばんごう (bangou)
Meaning: “number”
Use Context: Refers to numbers like phone, room, ID.
Placement in sentence: Noun; usually with の or を.
Examples:
1. でんわばんごうはなんですか。(Denwa bangou wa nan desu ka.) → What is the phone number?
2. このばんごうをつかってください。(Kono bangou o tsukatte kudasai.) → Please use this number.
3. ルームばんごうはいくつですか。(Ruumu bangou wa ikutsu desu ka.) → What is the room number?
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: なんばん (nan-ban)
Meaning: “what number?”
Use Context: Interrogative for asking about numbers (e.g., phone, bus, room).
Placement in sentence: Question noun; often with particle は.
Examples:
1. でんわばんごうはなんばんですか。(Denwa bangou wa nan-ban desu ka.) → What is the phone number?
2. このバスはなんばんですか。(Kono basu wa nan-ban desu ka.) → What number bus is this?
3. あなたのへやはなんばんですか。(Anata no heya wa nan-ban desu ka.) → What is your room number?
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: ～から (~kara)
Meaning: “from ~”
Use Context: Indicates a starting point in time or place.
Placement in sentence: Suffix; follows nouns or times.
Examples:
1. くじからはたらきます。(Ku-ji kara hatarakimasu.) → I work from 9 o’clock.
2. ここからいきます。(Koko kara ikimasu.) → I go from here.
3. いちがつからべんきょうします。(Ichigatsu kara benkyou shimasu.) → I study from January.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: ～まで (~made)
Meaning: “until ~ / to ~”
Use Context: Indicates an end point in time or place.
Placement in sentence: Suffix; follows nouns or times.
Examples:
1. ごじまでべんきょうします。(Go-ji made benkyou shimasu.) → I study until 5 o’clock.
2. あそこまであるきます。(Asoko made arukimasu.) → I walk until there.
3. きょうまでやすみです。(Kyou made yasumi desu.) → The holiday is until today.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: ～と～ (~to~)
Meaning: “and (noun connector)”
Use Context: Used to connect nouns.
Placement in sentence: Between two nouns.
Examples:
1. パンとミルクをたべます。(Pan to miruku o tabemasu.) → I eat bread and drink milk.
2. にほんとバングラデシュ。(Nihon to Banguradeshu.) → Japan and Bangladesh.
3. わたしとあなたはともだちです。(Watashi to anata wa tomodachi desu.) → You and I are friends.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: そちら (sochira)
Meaning: “that way / there / you (polite)”
Use Context: Polite alternative for そこ; also used to address the listener.
Placement in sentence: Functions as noun; with は, に, へ.
Examples:
1. そちらはどうですか。(Sochira wa dou desu ka.) → How are things there?
2. そちらにいきます。(Sochira ni ikimasu.) → I’ll go there.
3. そちらはにほんですか。(Sochira wa Nihon desu ka.) → Is that Japan?
Politeness: Polite/formal.

Details: たいへんですね (taihen desu ne)
Meaning: “That’s tough, isn’t it?”
Use Context: Used to show sympathy or understanding.
Placement in sentence: Fixed expression.
Examples:
1. しごとはたいへんですね。(Shigoto wa taihen desu ne.) → Work is hard, isn’t it?
2. びょうきはたいへんですね。(Byouki wa taihen desu ne.) → Being sick is tough, isn’t it?
3. あつくてたいへんですね。(Atsukute taihen desu ne.) → It’s hot and tough, isn’t it?
Politeness: Polite (ね makes it softer).

Details: えーと (ee to)
Meaning: “um… / let me see…”
Use Context: Used to pause in conversation, thinking filler.
Placement in sentence: Interjection; usually at sentence start.
Examples:
1. えーと、なにをいいますか。(Ee to, nani o iimasu ka.) → Um, what should I say?
2. えーと、じゅうじです。(Ee to, juu-ji desu.) → Um, it’s 10 o’clock.
3. えーと、つぎはどこですか。(Ee to, tsugi wa doko desu ka.) → Um, where is next?
Politeness: Neutral/casual.

Details: おねがいします (onegai shimasu)
Meaning: “please / I request”
Use Context: Used when asking politely.
Placement in sentence: Expression; often at end of request.
Examples:
1. よろしくおねがいします。(Yoroshiku onegai shimasu.) → Nice to meet you / please take care of it.
2. メニューをおねがいします。(Menyuu o onegai shimasu.) → The menu, please.
3. コーヒーをおねがいします。(Koohii o onegai shimasu.) → Coffee, please.
Politeness: Polite.

Details: かしこまりました (kashikomarimashita)
Meaning: “Certainly / Understood” (very polite)
Use Context: Used by staff when accepting requests.
Placement in sentence: Fixed phrase.
Examples:
1. コーヒーですね。かしこまりました。(Koohii desu ne. Kashikomarimashita.) → Coffee? Certainly.
2. ごちゅうもんをかしこまりました。(Gochuumon o kashikomarimashita.) → I have received your order.
3. しょうしょうおまちください。かしこまりました。(Shoushou omachi kudasai. Kashikomarimashita.) → Please wait a moment. Certainly.
Politeness: Very polite/honorific.

column1: おといあわせのばんごう
column3:
Details: おといあわせのばんごう (otoiawase no bangou)
Meaning: “inquiry number / reference number”
Use Context: Used in formal contexts for inquiries or customer service.
Placement in sentence: Noun phrase; with は, です.
Examples:
1. おといあわせのばんごうは123です。(Otoiawase no bangou wa 123 desu.) → The inquiry number is 123.
2. おといあわせのばんごうをおしえてください。(Otoiawase no bangou o oshiete kudasai.) → Please tell me the inquiry number.
3. おといあわせのばんごうはこちらです。(Otoiawase no bangou wa kochira desu.) → Here is the inquiry number.
Politeness: Polite/formal.

column1: どうもありがとうございました
column2: Thank you very much (for what you did).
column3:
Details: どうもありがとうございました (doumo arigatou gozaimashita)
Meaning: “Thank you very much (for what you did).”
Use Context: Polite gratitude, often for completed actions.
Placement in sentence: Set phrase.
Examples:
1. きのうはどうもありがとうございました。(Kinou wa doumo arigatou gozaimashita.) → Thank you very much for yesterday.
2. プレゼントをどうもありがとうございました。(Purezento o doumo arigatou gozaimashita.) → Thank you very much for the present.
3. ごしゅっせきどうもありがとうございました。(Go shusseki doumo arigatou gozaimashita.) → Thank you very much for attending.
Politeness: Very polite.

Details: ニューヨーク (Nyuu Yooku)
Meaning: “New York”
Use Context: City name.
Placement in sentence: Proper noun; with は, に, から.
Examples:
1. ニューヨークからきました。(Nyuu Yooku kara kimashita.) → I came from New York.
2. ニューヨークにすんでいます。(Nyuu Yooku ni sunde imasu.) → I live in New York.
3. ニューヨークはおおきいです。(Nyuu Yooku wa ookii desu.) → New York is big.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: ペキン (Pekin)
Meaning: “Beijing”
Use Context: Capital of China.
Placement in sentence: Proper noun.
Examples:
1. ペキンからきました。(Pekin kara kimashita.) → I came from Beijing.
2. ペキンはちゅうごくのしゅとです。(Pekin wa Chuugoku no shuto desu.) → Beijing is the capital of China.
3. ペキンにいきたいです。(Pekin ni ikitai desu.) → I want to go to Beijing.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: ロンドン (Rondon)
Meaning: “London”
Use Context: City name.
Placement in sentence: Proper noun.
Examples:
1. ロンドンはイギリスのしゅとです。(Rondon wa Igirisu no shuto desu.) → London is the capital of the UK.
2. ロンドンにいきます。(Rondon ni ikimasu.) → I am going to London.
3. ロンドンからかえりました。(Rondon kara kaerimashita.) → I returned from London.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: バンコク (Bankoku)
Meaning: “Bangkok”
Use Context: Capital of Thailand.
Placement in sentence: Proper noun.
Examples:
1. バンコクはタイのしゅとです。(Bankoku wa Tai no shuto desu.) → Bangkok is the capital of Thailand.
2. バンコクにいきました。(Bankoku ni ikimashita.) → I went to Bangkok.
3. バンコクからきました。(Bankoku kara kimashita.) → I came from Bangkok.
Politeness: Neutral.

Details: ロサンゼルス (Rosanzerusu)
Meaning: “Los Angeles”
Use Context: City in the USA.
Placement in sentence: Proper noun.
Examples:
1. ロサンゼルスにすんでいます。(Rosanzerusu ni sunde imasu.) → I live in Los Angeles.
2. ロサンゼルスからきました。(Rosanzerusu kara kimashita.) → I came from Los Angeles.
3. ロサンゼルスはおおきなまちです。(Rosanzerusu wa ookina machi desu.) → Los Angeles is a big city.
Politeness: Neutral.
